steps.title: Place a receptacle for the old radiator fluid below the radiator’s drain.
steps.content: Place a receptacle for the old radiator fluid below the radiator’s drain. Typical vehicle radiators hold 2-3 gallons (7.57-11.35 L) of liquid. Check your owner’s manual for your vehicle to see how much radiator fluid it holds so you use a container that is big enough. Use a sealable container, or have one handy to transfer the fluid into, so that you can safely dispose of the old radiator fluid later on. The coolant contains antifreeze and other chemicals which are toxic. Never pour it down a drain.

steps.title: Turn the radiator’s temperature control to the hottest setting.
steps.content: Turn the radiator’s temperature control to the hottest setting. There will be a thermostat located near the radiator. Turn it up all the way to allow the most flow of liquid through the radiator. [1] X Research source Check your vehicle’s owner’s manual if you aren’t sure where the temperature control is or how to set it to the highest setting.

steps.title: Twist off and remove the pressure cap and the drain cap if there is one.
steps.content: Twist off and remove the pressure cap and the drain cap if there is one. The radiator’s pressure cap is located at the top of the radiator. The drain cap will be located at the bottom near the bottom hose, if there is one. [2] X Research source Use a rag to remove the pressure cap if it is hard to twist and pull off. If there is no drain cap on your radiator, then disconnect the bottom hose at this point to let the radiator fluid drain out that hole.

steps.title: Let all the old radiator fluid drain out into the receptacle.
steps.content: Let all the old radiator fluid drain out into the receptacle. The radiator fluid will come out of the bottom drain if there is one. It will drain from where you disconnected the bottom hose if you disconnected that instead. [3] X Research source Poke a piece of wire or a wire brush into the hole and wiggle it around to clear it if the liquid does not start draining out right away on its own.

steps.title: Seal the receptacle for proper disposal later on.
steps.content: Seal the receptacle for proper disposal later on. Seal up the container full of old coolant after the radiator stops draining. Set it aside so that you can safely dispose of it later on. Contact a local recycling center, hazardous waste disposal company, or mechanic to dispose safely of the old radiator fluid.

steps.title: Disconnect both radiator hoses from the radiator.
steps.content: Disconnect both radiator hoses from the radiator. There is 1 hose at the top and 1 hose at the bottom. They will both be connected by some kind of clamp to the radiator. If you see a screw on the clamps that connect the hoses, you need to loosen the screw to disconnect the hoses. If there is no screw, then the clamp is a tension clamp that you need to squeeze with pliers to loosen.

steps.title: Insert a garden hose into the top radiator hose hole and seal it with rags.
steps.content: Insert a garden hose into the top radiator hose hole and seal it with rags. Place the tip of the garden hose into the hole so that it is fully inserted. Wedge some clean rags around it to hold it in place and create a seal. Make sure that the hose is held really tightly in place in order to efficiently flush the radiator .

steps.title: Put the pressure cap back on the radiator.
steps.content: Put the pressure cap back on the radiator. Make sure to screw it on tightly. This will complete the seal so that you can flush the radiator. [4] X Research source Use a rag to twist the cap back on tightly if it is hard to do with your bare hands.

steps.title: Turn on the water supply to the garden hose.
steps.content: Turn on the water supply to the garden hose. Open up the valve to the faucet all the way. Leave the water running until it runs clear out the bottom of the radiator. [5] X Research source You won’t be able to tell if the water is completely clear just by looking at it flowing out the bottom. There are small sediments that you can only see in still water.

steps.title: Collect samples of the water that comes out with a glass jar until it runs clear.
steps.content: Collect samples of the water that comes out with a glass jar until it runs clear. Hold a glass jar under the water that is draining out to collect a sample. Hold it up to the light and inspect it for sediments. Repeat this until you attain a clear sample, then turn off the hose. [6] X Research source In most cases, it will just take a few minutes for the water to run clear.

steps.title: Reconnect both of the radiator hoses and the drain cap if there is one.
steps.content: Reconnect both of the radiator hoses and the drain cap if there is one. Put the hoses back on and secure them with the clamps. Reattach the radiator’s drain cap if you removed it earlier on. You can also replace the hoses at this point if either of them are damaged or worn out. You can get new hoses at an auto parts store.

steps.title: Set the temperature gauge back to the normal temperature.
steps.content: Set the temperature gauge back to the normal temperature. Set the temperature control back to where it was when you started. Consult your owner's manual if you aren't sure what temperature to set it to. [7] X Research source The normal temperature is that an engine operates at is about 220 °F (104 °C).

steps.title: Fill the radiator back up with radiator fluid that contains antifreeze.
steps.content: Fill the radiator back up with radiator fluid that contains antifreeze. Twist off the pressure cap again and pour in radiator fluid until you can see it almost at the top. Twist the pressure cap back on securely and your radiator will now be unclogged and full of clean fluid. [8] X Research source The new coolant will usually be good for 2-3 years or 30,000 miles, after which you will need to replace it again .
